content:
This is painfully hard to crack in Reverse if you don't think of the look-and-say sequence.

I spent a lot of time trying to find some mathematical relationship between the numbers, or operations between pairs of digits. I couldn't see the pattern easily from your 4 test cases. Would be nice to have one more test case pair, I think. Nice clash, though. :)

Using all digits makes this pattern much harder to see than when other strings are allowed ("1a3b" -> "abbb" is easy to see).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est simple et clair. Rapide à faire et se prête bien aux différents challenges (rapidité, taille de code ou même reverse).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accepted this contribution because it is short, fun, and actually simple if you get the logic, and pretty clear in my opinion!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a quick and entertaining challenge, the description is easy to understand and I had fun coding a solution myself.
Great puzzle, can be done very quickly and also with very little code. I'd like to see you allow all modes.
OK, done. This is my first contribution, and initially I was not very comfortable with giving explanations. I am happy you like the puzzle. Thank you.

Yes, all the difficulty is to understand that not all the numbers have the same meaning.
It is no easy to find test cases that really help...
Happy that you liked the clash!

Mmm...

Some examples that I think would help make it clear:

1022337182 -> 022333111111188888888
10345678 -> 0444666668888888
30212041 -> 00011001111

It's very useful to have some test cases where the output has a leading "0", because this makes it clear that it's not a mathematical problem, would make it less frustrating to solve. :)
Also, I think these longer examples are useful because it's a lot easier to see which digits are being used in the result and which digits are the 'multipliers'.
